BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger. Evening and night: Gradual increase in avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a strong wind from westerly directions, sometimes large wind slabs formed above the tree line. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on very steep north, east and south facing slopes. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. Careful route selection is advisable.
Wet avalanches during the day require caution. Dry and wet avalanches are possible during the course of the night, in particular medium-sized ones.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions there is more snow than usual.
5 to 15 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 2000 m.
The covering of new snow is soft.
The upper section of the snowpack is largely stable and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a crust. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on steep, little used shady slopes. Towards its base, the snowpack is well consolidated.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Monday: The weather will be mild. During the day: Up to the tree line rain will fall. New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger, especially along the border with France.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a strong wind from westerly directions, sometimes large wind slabs formed above the tree line. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on very steep north, east and south facing slopes. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. Careful route selection is advisable.
Wet avalanches during the day are possible. Dry and wet avalanches are possible during the course of the night, in particular medium-sized ones.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
5 to 10 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 2000 m.
The covering of new snow is soft.
The upper section of the snowpack is largely stable and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a crust. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on steep, little used shady slopes. Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Monday: The weather will be mild. During the day: Up to the tree line rain will fall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger, especially along the border with Switzerland.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
15 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since yesterday above approximately 1800 m.
In the last few days sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in all aspects. These must be evaluated with care and prudence above approximately 2400 m. Even single backcountry tourers can release avalanches in some places, including medium-sized ones. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible in isolated cases. Additionally avalanches can also penetrate down to the ground and reach quite a large size in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found on steep slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The fresh and older wind slabs are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures, snowfall and the occasionally storm force westerly wind, the snowpack could not consolidate. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in particular on northwest to east to south facing aspects. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions, depending on the infuence of the wind. Below the tree line only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of dry and moist avalanches being released will increase a little. In the event of rain this applies in particular.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Until the afternoon the wind will be strong. The fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. Some new snow at low altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. The fresh wind slabs can be released easily by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above approximately 2000 m. The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence above approximately 2200 m.
Weak layers in the old snowpack necessitate defensive route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The strong wind will transport the fresh and old snow significantly. The wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and generally at high altitudes. Wind slabs are in some cases small but can be released easily. Avalanche prone weak layers exist in the old snowpack in particular on shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and older wind slabs are prone to triggering in particular on northwest to north to southeast facing aspects above the tree line. In the regions with a lot of snow the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies on very steep slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.

On steep grassy slopes small to medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. This applies in particular in the regions with a lot of snow.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 15 cm of snow will fall until the early morning. In particular in the northwest and in the northeast in some regions up to 25 cm of snow will fall. As a consequence of the strong wind the wind slabs will increase in size during the night. This applies especially in the regions with a lot of snow. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force wind from northwesterly directions, further wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs remain in some cases prone to triggering above approximately 2400 m. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In isolated cases avalanches are medium-sized.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. The old snowpack is largely stable. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust below approximately 2600 m. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind.

From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Over a wide area over a wide area 5 to 10 cm of snow will fall above approximately 400 m. The new snow will be deposited on a favourable old snowpack in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs will be deposited on soft layers in all aspects. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in north to northeast to northwest facing aspects and on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of low temperatures and solar radiation the snowpack consolidated. The snowpack remains unfavourable in particular on very steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind and new snow, especially along the border with France. As the day progresses as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation there will be only a slight increase in the danger of dry and moist avalanches.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In the west 10 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since yesterday.
In the last few days sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed on north, east and southeast facing slopes. These must be evaluated with care and prudence above approximately 2500 m. Even single backcountry tourers can release avalanches in some places, including medium-sized ones. In some places avalanches can also be released in near-surface layers of the snowpack and reach medium size in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
The fresh and older wind slabs are to be avoided. The avalanche prone locations are to be found on steep slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The avalanche danger is close to the boundary with danger level 3 (considerable).
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures, snowfall and the occasionally storm force westerly wind, the snowpack could not consolidate. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in particular on northwest to east to south facing aspects. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions, depending on the infuence of the wind. Below the tree line only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of snow slides and avalanches being released will increase. In the event of rain this applies in particular. The avalanche danger will increase during the day, reaching danger level 3 (considerable).

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist snow slides and avalanches being released will increase.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In the last few days sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in high Alpine regions. Some fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can be released easily or naturally especially on north to east to south facing aspects above approximately 2400 m.
In some places new snow is lying on an icy crust. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
Slight increase in danger of dry and moist avalanches as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all altitude zones less snow than usual is lying. Below approximately 2200 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. The snowpack is largely stable and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong melt-freeze crust. Towards its base, the snowpack is moist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanches can in isolated cases be released, in particular by large loads. This applies in particular on very steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes, and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. Wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Thus far only a little snow is lying. Wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and at elevated altitudes. They are mostly small.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be generally stable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow is lying on top of a quite favourable old snowpack in all aspects above approximately 400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack is fairly homogeneous and has a loosely bonded surface.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The more recent wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads,. Some new snow at low altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in the high Alpine regions. Wind slabs are easy to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind will transport only a little snow. The wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and generally at high altitudes. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are shallow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs in the high Alpine regions. The avalanche prone locations are rather rare.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: 5 to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since yesterday above approximately 2000 m. In some places new snow is lying on an icy crust. The small wind slabs of the last few days can be released in isolated cases on extremely steep shady slopes and generally in high Alpine regions. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all aspects as well as in all altitude zones from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. The snowpack is largely stable and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong crust. The avalanche prone locations are very rare.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs above approximately 1800 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche conditions are mostly favourable. Isolated small avalanches are possible in isolated cases. The avalanche prone locations are to be found especially in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will become generally stable. Adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls mostly small wind slabs formed.
